sub_topic: Finding the projection of one vector onto another using trigonometry
message_1: A force vector of magnitude 40 N acts at an angle of 30 degrees with respect to the horizontal axis. What is the magnitude of the horizontal projection of the force vector?
message_2:
To find the horizontal projection of the force vector, we can use the cosine function. The horizontal projection is given by:

Horizontal projection = Magnitude of force vector × cos(angle)

Here, the magnitude of the force vector is 40 N, and the angle is 30 degrees. First, we need to convert the angle from degrees to radians:

30 degrees × (π/180) = (30 × π)/180 = π/6 radians

Now, we can find the horizontal projection:

Horizontal projection = 40 N × cos(π/6)
Horizontal projection ≈ 40 N × 0.866025
Horizontal projection ≈ 34.641 N

The magnitude of the horizontal projection of the force vector is approximately 34.641 N.
